issues.description: The Rideable.messageOnRide method signature is inconsistent across artifacts: the problem statement (UML and textual description) and the template expect a no-argument method messageOnRide():String (and the template's Main calls r.messageOnRide() with no arguments), but the solution repository defines Rideable.messageOnRide(String equipment) and implements classes (Pig, Seal) accordingly. This parameter mismatch means the solution's Rideable API does not match the exercise specification and the template usage, which would confuse students and prevent direct reuse or comparison of the solution with the template (calls without an argument will not compile against the solution interface).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Rideable interface and its implementations with the problem statement and template. Either (A) remove the equipment parameter from Rideable.messageOnRide so it is messageOnRide():String, and update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() returning the specified phrase (e.g., "Riding on Pig Doodle"); or (B) if an equipment parameter is intended pedagogically, update the problem statement and template (including example calls in Main and the UML) to specify messageOnRide(String equipment). Option A is recommended to preserve the documented exercise requirements.

issues.description: The problem statement and template expect a no-argument method messageOnRide() (interface Rideable and usage in Main call r.messageOnRide()), but the solution implementation defines Rideable.messageOnRide(String equipment) and implements messageOnRide with a String parameter in Pig and Seal. This is a signature/name mismatch for the same conceptual operation (the animal-ride message). Students following the problem and template will implement and call a zero-argument messageOnRide(), while the solution requires a String parameter — creating a direct mapping/confusion error between requirement, starter code usage, and reference implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Rideable API across artifacts. Prefer matching the problem/template: change the solution to declare Rideable.messageOnRide() with no parameters and update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() returning the required string (e.g., "Riding on Pig Doodle"). Alternatively (less recommended), update the problem text and template usage to require and document an equipment parameter and update example calls accordingly — but the simpler correction is to remove the extra String parameter from the solution interface and implementations so all artifacts use messageOnRide() with no arguments.
